Award.AwardTitle: Solving large-scale eigen-related problems: Efficient and scalable algorithms
Award.AbstractNarration:
The main objectives of this project focus on novel efficient algorithms for solving large-scale eigen-related problems. The term "eigen-related" refers to any problem for which a solution can be expressed using certain eigenvalues and/or eigenvectors. Such eigen-related problems are central to a wide range of scientific and engineering disciplines, including materials science, statistical computing, data mining and machine learning. The ever-increasing high dimensions and complexity of modern scientific problems bring overwhelming computational burden for eigen-related computations and render existing eigen-algorithms ineffective. There is great demand for eigen-algorithms that can take into account the dynamic and nonlinear nature of modern scientific problems, leading to algorithms that can handle massive datasets more efficiently. The investigator proposes to systematically study and develop novel scalable approaches for alleviating the computational bottlenecks related to solving large-scale eigen-related problems. Approaches to be investigated include global spectrum filtering as well as multilevel sampling and clustering. Specifically, the investigator will develop methods (a) to reduce the diagonalization cost for density functional theory calculations; (b) to accelerate partial SVD calculations that are used in a significantly broad range of applications; and (c)to accelerate the low-rank matrix approximations via Nystrom-type methods.


Large eigen-related problems are ubiquitous in modern science, engineering, and economics applications. This project will develop efficient scalable algorithms for solving large eigen-related problems. One important broader impact of the proposed work is that the resulting methods will accelerate discoveries in a wide range of research fields, including material science and data mining, which are critical to national energy security and economic competitiveness. The project will also provide interesting and challenging topics for Ph.D. dissertation research, for undergraduate research, and for outreach activities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Large eigen-related problems are ubiquitous in modern science, engineering, and economics applications.The main objectives of the project focus on novel efficient algorithms for solving large eigen-related problems. The term "eigen-related" refers to any problem for which a solution can be expressed using eigenvalues and/or eigenvectors of certain matrices. Such eigen-related problems are central to a wide range of scientific and engineering disciplines, including materials science, statistical computing, data mining and machine learning.  Therefore, advances in efficient algorithms for large eigen-related problems can directly impact a broad range of disciplines. 


The outcomes of this project include the following:


1. A sparse diagonalization-free nonlinear subspace filtering method for the self-consistent field calculations in density functional theory (DFT). Since our method completely avoids the expensive sparse diagonalizations, it can be used for very large scale DFT calculations, enabling ab initio calculations of many thousand atoms in materials science.

2. A systematic study of the Teter-Payne-Allan (TPA) preconditioning function frequently used in plane-wave DFT calculations. We develop a general formula that can be used to readily generate a class of 'preconditioning' functions. Our formula can generate higher order approximation accuracy and fulfill the same essential 'preconditioning' purposes as the TPA function. 

3. A block Chebyshev-Davidson method for large linear response (LR) eigenvalue problems. LR problems have applications in quantum physics and chemistry, including time-dependent density-functional theory, computing the Bethe-Salperter equation excitation energies, and finding the electronic excitation spectrum of quantum many-fermion systems. A recent method developed for LR problems is LOB4DPCG (locally optimal block 4-D preconditioned CG), but this method is restricted to definite LR problems. Our method is applicable to both definite and indefinite LR problems, thus having broader applications.Moreover, our method is found to be about six to ten times faster than the recent LOB4DPCG on some definite problems.

4. Two filtered block Davidson methods for partial singular value decompositions (PSVD) and partial eigenvalue decompositions (PEVD).  One of our methods uses an optimal polynomial filter, the other uses a rational function filter approximated by a fixed-step conjugate residual (CR) method instead of the more commonly used conjugate gradient (CG) method. The reason is that our shift-invert matrices are indefinite, and CR is more stable than CG for indefinite linear equations. Our methods are compared with best available algorithms for PEVD and PSVD computations, including (1) PROPACK that is frequently employed for PSVD from data scientists, (2) ARPACK, which is the de facto software for eigenvalue problems, (3) The randomized SVD method, and (4) The limited memory SVD.  On realistic test problems, our methods use significantly less memory, but achieve similar or faster convergence speed. The far less memory demand makes our methods more suitable for large data.

5. An intrinsically parallel spectrum decomposition method for large eigenvalue calculations. In contrast to the existingmethods that use matrix factorizations in order to count number of eigenvalues on an interval, our method avoids such expensive factorizations. We also initiate and develop the shift-without-invert approach. The intrinsic parallelism is induced by spectrum partition. Furthermore, our 'without-invert' approach avoids the complexity associated with applying sparse linear equation solvers for approximating inverse.
